mods:mods.mods:abstract: Thanks him for his statements of opinion. Has learned that John Jay has since perused Dr. Hobart's statement on the other side of the question. Should it be necessary and should opportunity present itself, he would be able to set the several subjects in a different light from which they now appear. Several of the certificates can be overthrown, and others comprise meaningless testimonials. Dr. Beach will attest to the truth of Jones' remarks though Hobart denies them. Hobart's relinquishment of pretentions to the Episcopate is to be considered a condition of reconciliation "by burying everything in oblivion." Hobart has also misrepresented his last interview with Harris. Mr. How's statement is shown by example to be incorrect. Nothing will satisfy the opposing parties but Jones' removal. The vestry have assumed the controversy under the 32nd Canon of the Church and he has protested. Here matters will rest until the Convention. A proposition has been made to give Jones an annuity upon resignation. Requests Jay's advice on this point. If anything is attempted at the Convention it will undoubtedly be carried unless "some powerful friend" should come forth from the laity. Would Jay forego his retirement to protect the oppressed?
